para.sentence: (For other notation see LABEL:about.notations.)
integers.
real or complex constants.
real variables.
complex variable.
base of natural logarithms.
It is assumed the user is familiar with the definitions and properties of elementary functions of real arguments x.
The main purpose of the present chapter is to extend these definitions and properties to complex arguments z.

The main functions treated in this chapter are the logarithm \ln z , \operatorname{Ln}z ; the exponential \exp z , e^{z} ; the circular trigonometric (or just trigonometric) functions \sin z , \cos z , \tan z , \csc z , \sec z , \cot z ; the inverse trigonometric functions \operatorname{arcsin}z , \operatorname{Arcsin}z , etc.; the hyperbolic trigonometric (or just hyperbolic) functions \sinh z , \cosh z , \tanh z , \operatorname{csch}z , \operatorname{sech}z , \coth z ; the inverse hyperbolic functions \operatorname{arcsinh}z , \operatorname{Arcsinh}z , etc.

Sometimes in the literature the meanings of \ln and \operatorname{Ln} are interchanged; similarly for \operatorname{arcsin}z and \operatorname{Arcsin}z , etc. Sometimes “arc” is replaced by the index “ -1 ”, e.g. {\sin^{-1}}z for \operatorname{arcsin}z and \mathrm{Sin}^{-1}\;z for \operatorname{Arcsin}z.

subsection.title: The Logarithm

para.sentence: The general logarithm function \operatorname{Ln}z is defined by \operatorname{Ln}z=\int_{1}^{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{t}, subject to z\neq 0, where the integration path does not intersect the origin.
This is a multivalued function of z with branch point at z=0.
The principal value, or principal branch, is defined by \ln z=\int_{1}^{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{t}, where the path does not intersect (-\infty,0] ; see FigureLABEL:fig:EF.LO.LOG1.
\ln z is a single-valued analytic function on \mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0] and real-valued when z ranges over the positive real numbers.

subsection.sentence: Figure 4.2.1: z -plane: Branch cut for \ln z and z^{\alpha} .

para.sentence: The real and imaginary parts of \ln z are given by \ln z=\ln\left|z\right|+\mathrm{i}\operatorname{ph}z, subject to -\pi<\operatorname{ph}z<\pi.
For \operatorname{ph}z see §LABEL:sec:AL.CC.cn.
The only zero of \ln z is at z=1.

Most texts extend the definition of the principal value to include thebranch cut z=x, subject to -\infty<x<0, by replacing (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PA) with \ln z=\ln\left|z\right|+\mathrm{i}\operatorname{ph}z, subject to -\pi<\operatorname{ph}z\leq\pi.

With this definition the general logarithm is given by \operatorname{Ln}z=\ln z+2k\pi\mathrm{i}, where k is the excess of the number of times the path in (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.LL) crosses the negative real axis in the positive sense over the number of times in the negative sense.

In the DLMF we allow a further extension by regarding the cut as representing two sets of points, one set corresponding to the “upper side” and denoted by z=x+\mathrm{i}0 , the other set corresponding to the “lower side” and denoted by z=x-\mathrm{i}0.
Again see Figure LABEL:fig:EF.LO.LOG1.
Then \ln\left(x\pm\mathrm{i}0\right)=\ln|x|\pm i\pi, subject to -\infty<x<0, with either upper signs or lower signs taken throughout.
Consequently \ln z is two-valued on the cut, and discontinuous across the cut.
We regard this as the closed definition of the principal value.
In contrast to (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PA2) the closed definition is symmetric.
As a consequence, it has the advantage of extending regions of validity of properties of principal values.

For example, with the definition(LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PA2) the identity (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PP.1) is valid only when \left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|<\pi , but with the closed definition the identity (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PP.1) is valid when \left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|\leq\pi.
For another example see (LABEL:eq:EF.PVEX).

In the DLMF it is usually clear from the context which definition of principal value is being used. However, in the absence of any indication to the contrary it is assumed that the definition is the closed one.
For other examples in this chapter see §§LABEL:sec:EF.INV,LABEL:sec:EF.ITF, LABEL:sec:EF.IHF, and LABEL:sec:EF.IHFF.

subsection.title: Logarithms to a General Base a

para.sentence: With a,b\neq 0 or 1 , \operatorname{log}_{a}z=\ifrac{\ln z}{\ln a}, , \operatorname{log}_{a}z=\frac{\operatorname{log}_{b}z}{\operatorname{log}_{b}a}, , \operatorname{log}_{a}b=\frac{1}{\operatorname{log}_{b}a}.
Natural logarithms have as base the unique positive number e=2.71828\ 18284\ 59045\ 23536\dots such that \ln e=1.
Equivalently, \int_{1}^{e}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{t}=1.

Thus \operatorname{log}_{e}z=\ln z, \operatorname{log}_{10}z=\ifrac{(\ln z)}{(\ln 10)}=(\operatorname{log}_{10}e) \ln z, \ln z=(\ln 10)\operatorname{log}_{10}z, \operatorname{log}_{10}e=0.43429\ 44819\ 03251\ 82765\dots, \ln 10=2.30258\ 50929\ 94045\ 68401\dots.
\operatorname{log}_{e}x=\ln x is also called the Napierian orhyperbolic logarithm.
\operatorname{log}_{10}x is the common orBriggs logarithm.
The function \exp is an entire function of z , with no real or complex zeros.
It has period 2\pi i : \exp\left(z+2\pi i\right)=\exp z.
Also, \exp\left(-z\right)=1/\exp\left(z\right).
|\exp z|=\exp\left(\Re z\right).
The general value of the phase is given by \operatorname{ph}\left(\exp z\right)=\Im z+2k\pi, subject to k\in\mathbb{Z}.
If z=x+iy , then \exp z=e^{x}\cos y+ie^{x}\sin y.
If \zeta\neq 0 then \exp z=\zeta\;\;\Longleftrightarrow\;\;z=\operatorname{Ln}\zeta.
The general a^{\rm th} power of z is defined by z^{a}=\exp\left(a\operatorname{Ln}z\right), subject to z\neq 0.
In particular, z^{0}=1 , and if a=n=1,2,3,\dots , then z^{a}=\underbrace{z\cdot z\cdots z}_{n\text{ times}}=1/z^{-a}.
In all other cases, z^{a} is a multivalued function with branch point at z=0.
The principal value is z^{a}=\exp\left(a\ln z\right).
This is an analytic function of z on \mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0] , and is two-valued and discontinuous on the cut shown in Figure LABEL:fig:EF.LO.LOG1, unless a\in\mathbb{Z}.

|z^{a}|=|z|^{\Re a}\exp\left(-(\Im a)\operatorname{ph}z\right), \operatorname{ph}\left(z^{a}\right)=(\Re a)\operatorname{ph}z+(\Im a)\ln|z|, where \operatorname{ph}z\in[-\pi,\pi] for the principal value of z^{a} , and is unrestricted in the general case.
When a is real |z^{a}|=|z|^{a}, \operatorname{ph}\left(z^{a}\right)=a\operatorname{ph}z.
Unless indicated otherwise, it is assumed throughout the DLMF that a power assumes its principal value.
With this convention, e^{z}=\exp z, but the general value of e^{z} is e^{z}=(\exp z)\exp\left(2kz\pi\mathrm{i}\right), subject to k\in\mathbb{Z}.
If z^{a} has its general value, with a\neq 0 , and if w\neq 0 , then z^{a}=w\;\;\Longleftrightarrow\;\;z=\exp\left(\frac{1}{a}\operatorname{Ln}w \right).
This result is also valid when z^{a} has its principal value, provided that the branch of \operatorname{Ln}w satisfies -\pi\leq\Im\left(\frac{1}{a}\operatorname{Ln}w\right)\leq\pi.

Another example of a principal value is provided by \sqrt{z^{2}}=\begin{cases}z,&\Re z\geq 0,\\ -z,&\Re z\leq 0.\end{cases} Again, without the closed definition the \geq and \leq signs would have to be replaced by > and < , respectively.

subsection.title: Real Arguments
subsection.sentence: Figure 4.3.1: \ln x and e^{x} . Parallel tangent lines at (1,0) and (0,1) make evident the mirror symmetry across the line y=x , demonstrating the inverse relationship between the two functions.

subsection.title: Complex Arguments: Conformal Maps

para.sentence: Figure LABEL:fig:EF.LOG.GRA.CA.1 illustrates the conformal mapping of the strip -\pi<\Im z<\pi onto the whole w -plane cut along the negative real axis, where w=e^{z} and z=\ln w (principal value).
Corresponding points share the same letters, with bars signifying complex conjugates.
Lines parallel to the real axis in the z -plane map onto rays in the w -plane, and lines parallel to the imaginary axis in the z -plane map onto circles centered at the origin in the w -plane.
In the labeling of corresponding points r is a real parameter that can lie anywhere in the interval (0,\infty).

subsection.sentence: Figure 4.3.2: Conformal mapping of exponential and logarithm. w=e^{z} , z=\ln w .

subsection.title: Complex Arguments: Surfaces

para.sentence: In the graphics shown in this subsection height corresponds to the absolute value of the function and color to the phase.
See also LABEL:doc.help.vrml.aboutcolor.

subsection.sentence: Figure 4.3.3: \ln\left(x+iy\right) (principal value). There is a branch cut along the negative real axis.

para.sentence: \ln 1=0, , \ln\left(-1\pm\mathrm{i}0\right)=\pm\pi\mathrm{i}, , \ln\left(\pm\mathrm{i}\right)=\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\pi\mathrm{i}.

e^{0}=1, , e^{\pm\pi\mathrm{i}}=-1, , e^{\pm\pi\mathrm{i}/2}=\pm\mathrm{i}, , e^{2\pi k\mathrm{i}}=1, subject to k\in\mathbb{Z}, , e^{\pm\pi\mathrm{i}/3}=\frac{1}{2}\pm\mathrm{i}\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}, , e^{\pm 2\pi\mathrm{i}/3}=-\frac{1}{2}\pm\mathrm{i}\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}, , e^{\pm\pi\mathrm{i}/4}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\pm\mathrm{i}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, , e^{\pm 3\pi\mathrm{i}/4}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\pm\mathrm{i}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, , {\mathrm{i}^{\pm\mathrm{i}}}=e^{\mp\pi/2}.

\lim_{x\to\infty}x^{-a}\ln x=0, subject to \Re a>0, \lim_{x\to 0}x^{a}\ln x=0, subject to \Re a>0, \lim_{x\to\infty}x^{a}e^{-x}=0, \lim_{z\to\infty}z^{a}e^{-z}=0, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi-\delta (<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi), where a ( \in\mathbb{C} ) and \delta ( \in(0,\tfrac{1}{2}\pi] ) are constants.
\lim_{n\to\infty}\left(1+\frac{z}{n}\right)^{n}=e^{z}, subject to z= constant.
\lim_{n\to\infty}\left(1+\frac{1}{n}\right)^{n}=e.
\lim_{n\to\infty}\left(\left(\sum^{n}_{k=1}\frac{1}{k}\right)-\ln n\right)= \gamma=0.57721\ 56649\ 01532\ 86060\dots, where \gamma is Euler’s constant; see (LABEL:eq:GA.Def.EC.1).

\frac{x}{1+x}<\ln\left(1+x\right)<x, subject to x>-1, x\neq 0, x<-\ln\left(1-x\right)<\frac{x}{1-x}, subject to x<1, x\neq 0, |\ln\left(1-x\right)|<\tfrac{3}{2}x, subject to 0<x\leq 0.5828\dots, \ln x\leq x-1, subject to x>0, \ln x\leq a(x^{1/a}-1), subject to a, x>0, |\ln\left(1+z\right)|\leq-\ln\left(1-|z|\right), subject to |z|<1.
For more inequalities involving the logarithm function see ( , pp. 75–77) , ( , pp. 272–276) , and ( , pp. 159–160) .
In (LABEL:eq:EF.EX.TA)–(LABEL:eq:EF.EX.TF) it is assumed that x\neq 0.
(When x=0 the inequalities become equalities.)

e^{-x/(1-x)}<1-x<e^{-x}, subject to x<1, 1+x<e^{x}, subject to -\infty<x<\infty, e^{x}<\frac{1}{1-x}, subject to x<1, \frac{x}{1+x}<1-e^{-x}<x, subject to x>-1, x<e^{x}-1<\frac{x}{1-x}, subject to x<1, e^{x/(1+x)}<1+x, subject to x>-1, e^{xy/(x+y)}<\left(1+\frac{x}{y}\right)^{y}<e^{x}, subject to x>0, y>0, e^{-x}<1-\tfrac{1}{2}x, subject to 0<x\leq 1.5936\dots , \tfrac{1}{4}|z|<|e^{z}-1|<\tfrac{7}{4}|z|, subject to 0<|z|<1, |e^{z}-1|\leq e^{|z|}-1\leq|z|e^{|z|}, subject to z\in\mathbb{C}.
For more inequalities involving the exponential function see ( , pp. 73–77) , ( , pp. 266–271) , and ( , pp. 81–83) .

\ln\left(z+a\right)=\ln a+2\left(\left(\frac{z}{2a+z}\right)+\frac{1}{3}\left( \frac{z}{2a+z}\right)^{3}+\frac{1}{5}\left(\frac{z}{2a+z}\right)^{5}+\cdots \right), subject to a>0, \Re z\geq-a, z\neq-a.
(1+z)^{a}=1+\frac{a}{1!}z+\frac{a(a-1)}{2!}z^{2}+\frac{a(a-1)(a-2)}{3!}z^{3}+\cdots , valid when a is any real or complex constant and |z|<1.

If a=0,1,2,\dots , then the series terminates and z is unrestricted. Note that (LABEL:eq:EF.EXP.BINO) is a generalization of the binomial expansion (LABEL:eq:AL.ES.BC.2) with the binomial coefficients defined in (LABEL:eq:AL.ES.BC.6).

\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\ln z=\frac{1}{z}, \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\operatorname{Ln}z=\frac{1}{z}, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}\ln z=(-1)^{n-1}(n-1)!z^{-n} , \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}\operatorname{Ln}z=(-1)^{n-1}(n-1)!z ^{-n}.

For a nonvanishing analytic function f(z) , the general solution of the differential equation \frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}=\frac{f^{\prime}(z)}{f(z)} is w(z)=\operatorname{Ln}\left(f(z)\right)+\hbox{ constant}.
When a^{z} is a general power, \ln a is replaced by the branch of \operatorname{Ln}a used in constructing a^{z}.
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}z^{a}=az^{a-1}, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}z^{a}=a(a-1)(a-2)\cdots(a-n+1)z^{a-n}.
The general solution of the differential equation \frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}=f(z)w is w=\exp\left(\int f(z)\mathrm{d}z\right)+{\rm constant}.
The general solution of the differential equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=aw, subject to a\neq 0, is w=Ae^{\sqrt{a}z}+Be^{-\sqrt{a}z}, where A and B are arbitrary constants.
For other differential equations see ( , pp. 396–413) .
In (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PR)–(LABEL:eq:EF.LO.FF) z_{1}z_{2}\neq 0.
\operatorname{Ln}\left(z_{1}z_{2}\right)=\operatorname{Ln}z_{1}+\operatorname{ Ln}z_{2}.
This is interpreted that every value of \operatorname{Ln}\left(z_{1}z_{2}\right) is one of the values of \operatorname{Ln}z_{1}+\operatorname{Ln}z_{2} , and vice versa.

\ln\left(z_{1}z_{2}\right)=\ln z_{1}+\ln z_{2}, subject to -\pi\leq\operatorname{ph}z_{1}+\operatorname{ph}z_{2}\leq\pi, \operatorname{Ln}\frac{z_{1}}{z_{2}}=\operatorname{Ln}z_{1}-\operatorname{Ln}z _{2}, \ln\frac{z_{1}}{z_{2}}=\ln z_{1}-\ln z_{2}, subject to -\pi\leq\operatorname{ph}z_{1}-\operatorname{ph}z_{2}\leq\pi.
In (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PO)–(LABEL:eq:EF.LO.PP.1) and (LABEL:eq:EF.EX.SD) z\neq 0.

\operatorname{Ln}\left(z^{n}\right)=n\operatorname{Ln}z, subject to n\in\mathbb{Z}, \ln\left(z^{n}\right)=n\ln z, subject to n\in\mathbb{Z}, -\pi\leq n\operatorname{ph}z\leq\pi, \ln\frac{1}{z}=-\ln z, subject to |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi.

\operatorname{Ln}\left(\exp z\right)=z+2k\pi\mathrm{i}, subject to k\in\mathbb{Z}, \ln\left(\exp z\right)=z, subject to -\pi\leq\Im z\leq\pi, \exp\left(\ln z\right)=\exp\left(\operatorname{Ln}z\right)=z.
If a\neq 0 and a^{z} has its general value, then \operatorname{Ln}\left(a^{z}\right)=z\operatorname{Ln}a+2k\pi\mathrm{i}, subject to k\in\mathbb{Z}.
If a\neq 0 and a^{z} has its principal value, then \ln\left(a^{z}\right)=z\ln a+2k\pi\mathrm{i}, where the integer k is chosen so that \Re(-\mathrm{i}z\ln a)+2k\pi\in[-\pi,\pi].
\ln\left(a^{x}\right)=x\ln a, subject to a>0.

a^{z_{1}}a^{z_{2}}=a^{z_{1}+z_{2}}, , a^{z}b^{z}=(ab)^{z}, subject to -\pi\leq\operatorname{ph}a+\operatorname{ph}b\leq\pi, , e^{z_{1}}e^{z_{2}}=e^{z_{1}+z_{2}}, , (e^{z_{1}})^{z_{2}}=e^{z_{1}z_{2}}, subject to -\pi\leq\Im z_{1}\leq\pi.
The restriction on z_{1} can be removed when z_{2} is an integer.
\ln\left(1+z\right)=\cfrac{z}{1+\cfrac{z}{2+\cfrac{z}{3+\cfrac{4z}{4+\cfrac{4z }{5+\cfrac{9z}{6+\cfrac{9z}{7+}}}}}}}\cdots, subject to |\operatorname{ph}\left(1+z\right)|<\pi.

\ln\left(\frac{1+z}{1-z}\right)=\cfrac{2z}{1-\cfrac{z^{2}}{3-\cfrac{4z^{2}}{5- \cfrac{9z^{2}}{7-\cfrac{16z^{2}}{9-}}}}}\cdots, valid when z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,-1]\cup[1,\infty) ; see FigureLABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(i).
For other continued fractions involving logarithms see ( , pp. 566–568) .
See also ( , pp. 196–200) .

For z\in\mathbb{C} , e^{z}=\cfrac{1}{1-\cfrac{z}{1+\cfrac{z}{2-\cfrac{z}{3+\cfrac{z}{2-\cfrac{z}{5+ \cfrac{z}{2-}}}}}}}\cdots, =1+\cfrac{z}{1-\cfrac{z}{2+\cfrac{z}{3-\cfrac{z}{2+\cfrac{z}{5-\cfrac{z}{2+ \cfrac{z}{7-}}}}}}}\cdots, =1+\cfrac{z}{1-(z/2)+\cfrac{z^{2}/(4\cdot 3)}{1+\cfrac{z^{2}/(4\cdot 15)}{1+ \cfrac{z^{2}/(4\cdot 35)}{1+}}}}\cdots\cfrac{z^{2}/(4(4n^{2}-1))}{1+}\cdots e^{z}-e_{n-1}(z)={\cfrac{z^{n}}{n!-\cfrac{n!z}{(n+1)+\cfrac{z}{(n+2)-\cfrac{(n +1)z}{(n+3)+\cfrac{2z}{(n+4)-}}}}}\cfrac{(n+2)z}{(n+5)+\cfrac{3z}{(n+6)-}} \cdots}, where e_{n}(z)=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\frac{z^{k}}{k!}.
For other continued fractions involving the exponential function see ( , pp. 563–564) .
See also ( , pp. 193–195) .

\int\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{z}=\ln z, \int\ln z\mathrm{d}z=z\ln z-z, \int z^{n}\ln z\mathrm{d}z=\frac{z^{n+1}}{n+1}\ln z-\frac{z^{n+1}}{(n+1)^{2}}, subject to n\neq-1, \int\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{z\ln z}=\ln\left(\ln z\right), \int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln t}{1-t}\mathrm{d}t=-\frac{\pi^{2}}{6}, \int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln t}{1+t}\mathrm{d}t=-\frac{\pi^{2}}{12}, \pvint_{0}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\ln t}=\mathrm{li}\left(x\right), subject to x>1.
The left-hand side of (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.DM) is a Cauchy principal value (§LABEL:sec:AL.COO.di).
For \mathrm{li}\left(x\right) see §LABEL:sec:EX.DF.EI.

For a,b\neq 0 , \int e^{az}\mathrm{d}z=\frac{e^{az}}{a}, \int\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{e^{az}+b}=\frac{1}{ab}(az-\ln\left(e^{az}+b\right)), \int\frac{e^{az}-1}{e^{az}+1}\mathrm{d}z=\frac{2}{a}\ln\left(e^{az/2}+e^{-az/2 }\right), \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-cx^{2}}\mathrm{d}x=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{c}}, subject to \Re c>0, \int_{0}^{\ln 2}\frac{xe^{x}}{e^{x}-1}\mathrm{d}x=\frac{\pi^{2}}{12}, \int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{e^{x}+1}=\ln 2.

Extensive compendia of indefinite and definite integrals of logarithms and exponentials include ( , pp. 16–47) , ( ) , ( , pp. 107–116) , ( , pp. 52–90) , ( , Chapters 2–4) , and ( , §§1.3, 1.6, 2.3, 2.6) .
For infinite series involving logarithms and/or exponentials, see ( , Chapter 1) , ( , §44) , and ( , Chapter 5) .
A generalized exponential function \phi(x) satisfies the equations \phi(x+1)=e^{\phi(x)}, subject to -1<x<\infty, , \phi(0)=0, and is strictly increasing when 0\leq x\leq 1.
Its inverse \psi(x) is called a generalized logarithm.
It, too, is strictly increasing when 0\leq x\leq 1 , and \psi(e^{x})=1+\psi(x), subject to -\infty<x<\infty, , \psi(0)=0.
These functions are not unique.
The simplest choice is given by \phi(x)=\psi(x)=x, subject to 0\leq x\leq 1.

Then \phi(x)=\ln\left(x+1\right), subject to -1<x<0, and \phi(x)=\exp\exp\cdots\exp\left(x-\left\lfloor x\right\rfloor\right), subject to x>1, where the exponentiations are carried out \left\lfloor x\right\rfloor times.

Correspondingly, \psi(x)=e^{x}-1, subject to -\infty<x<0, and \psi(x)=\ell+{\ln^{(\ell)}}x, subject to x>1, where {\ln^{(\ell)}}x denotes the \ell -th repeated logarithm of x , and \ell is the positive integer determined by the condition 0\leq{\ln^{(\ell)}}x<1.
Both \phi(x) and \psi(x) are continuously differentiable.
For further information, see ( ) .
For C^{\infty} generalized logarithms, see ( ) .
For analytic generalized logarithms, see ( ) .

section.title: Lambert W-Function

para.sentence: The Lambert W -function W\left(x\right) is the solution of the equation We^{W}=x.
On the x -interval [0,\infty) there is one real solution, and it is nonnegative and increasing.
On the x -interval (-1/e,0) there are two realsolutions, one increasing and the other decreasing.
We call the solution for which W\left(x\right)\geq W\left(-1/e\right) the principal branch and denote it by \mathrm{Wp}\left(x\right).
The other solution is denoted by \mathrm{Wm}\left(x\right).
See Figure LABEL:fig:EF.LAMB.FCN.2.

section.sentence: Figure 4.13.1: Branches \mathrm{Wp}\left(x\right) and \mathrm{Wm}\left(x\right) of the Lambert W -function. A and B denote the points -1/e and e , respectively, on the x -axis.

para.sentence: Properties include: \mathrm{Wp}\left(-1/e\right)=\mathrm{Wm}\left(-1/e\right)=-1, \mathrm{Wp}\left(0\right)=0, \mathrm{Wp}\left(e\right)=1.
U+\ln U=x, U=U(x)=W\left(e^{x}\right).
\frac{\mathrm{d}W}{\mathrm{d}x}=\frac{e^{-W}}{1+W}, subject to x\neq-\dfrac{1}{e}.
\mathrm{Wp}\left(x\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n-1}\frac{n^{n-2}}{(n-1)!}x ^{n}, subject to |x|<\dfrac{1}{e}.

W\left(-e^{-1-(t^{2}/2)}\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n-1}c_{n}t^{n}, subject to |t|<2\sqrt{\pi}, where t\geq 0 for \mathrm{Wp} , t\leq 0 for \mathrm{Wm} , c_{0}=1,c_{1}=1,c_{2}=\tfrac{1}{3},c_{3}=\tfrac{1}{36},c_{4}=-\tfrac{1}{270}, c_{n}=\frac{1}{n+1}\left(c_{n-1}-\sum_{k=2}^{n-1}kc_{k}c_{n+1-k}\right), subject to n\geq 2, and 1\cdot 3\cdot 5\cdots(2n+1)c_{2n+1}=g_{n}, where g_{n} is defined in §LABEL:sec:GA.AE.PE.
As x\to+\infty \mathrm{Wp}\left(x\right)=\xi-\ln\xi+\frac{\ln\xi}{\xi}+\frac{(\ln\xi)^{2}}{2 \xi^{2}}-\frac{\ln\xi}{\xi^{2}}+O\left(\frac{(\ln\xi)^{3}}{\xi^{3}}\right), where \xi=\ln x.

As x\to 0- \mathrm{Wm}\left(x\right)=-\eta-\ln\eta-\frac{\ln\eta}{\eta}-\frac{(\ln\eta)^{ 2}}{2\eta^{2}}-\frac{\ln\eta}{\eta^{2}}+O\left(\frac{(\ln\eta)^{3}}{\eta^{3}} \right), where \eta=\ln\left(-1/x\right).
For the foregoing results and further information see ( ) , ( ) , ( , pp. 25–28) , ( , pp. 12–13) , and ( ) .
For integral representations of all branches of the Lambert W -function see ( ) .
For a generalization of the Lambert W -function connected to the three-body problem see ( ) , ( ) and ( ) .

\sin z=\frac{e^{\mathrm{i}z}-e^{-\mathrm{i}z}}{2\mathrm{i}}, , \cos z=\frac{e^{\mathrm{i}z}+e^{-\mathrm{i}z}}{2}, , \cos z\pm i\sin z=e^{\pm iz}, , \tan z=\frac{\sin z}{\cos z}, , \csc z=\frac{1}{\sin z}, , \sec z=\frac{1}{\cos z}, , \cot z=\frac{\cos z}{\sin z}=\frac{1}{\tan z}.
The functions \sin z and \cos z are entire.
In \mathbb{C} the zeros of \sin z are z=k\pi , k\in\mathbb{Z} ; the zeros of \cos z are z=\left(k+\tfrac{1}{2}\right)\pi , k\in\mathbb{Z}.
The functions \tan z , \csc z , \sec z , and \cot z are meromorphic, and the locations of their zeros and poles follow from (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.AC) to (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.AF).
For k\in\mathbb{Z} \sin\left(z+2k\pi\right)=\sin z, , \cos\left(z+2k\pi\right)=\cos z, , \tan\left(z+k\pi\right)=\tan z.

subsection.title: Real Arguments
subsection.sentence: Figure 4.15.2: \operatorname{Arcsin}x and \operatorname{Arccos}x . Principal values are shown with thickened lines.
Figure 4.15.4: \operatorname{arctan}x and \operatorname{arccot}x . Only principal values are shown. \operatorname{arccot}x is discontinuous at x=0 .
Figure 4.15.6: \operatorname{arccsc}x and \operatorname{arcsec}x . Only principal values are shown. (Both functions are complex when -1<x<1 .)

subsection.title: Complex Arguments: Conformal Maps

para.sentence: Figure LABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.CAC.1 illustrates the conformal mapping of the strip -\tfrac{1}{2}\pi<\Re z<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi onto the whole w -plane cut along the real axis from -\infty to -1 and 1 to \infty , where w=\sin z and z=\operatorname{arcsin}w (principal value).
Corresponding points share the same letters, with bars signifying complex conjugates.

Lines parallel to the real axis in the z -plane map onto ellipses in the w -plane with foci at w=\pm 1 , and lines parallel to the imaginary axis in the z -plane map onto rectangular hyperbolas confocal with the ellipses.
In the labeling of corresponding points r is a real parameter that can lie anywhere in the interval (0,\infty).

subsection.sentence: Figure 4.15.7: Conformal mapping of sine and inverse sine. w=\sin z , z=\operatorname{arcsin}w .

subsection.title: Complex Arguments: Surfaces

para.sentence: In the graphics shown in this subsection height corresponds to the absolute value of the function and color to the phase.
See also LABEL:doc.help.vrml.aboutcolor.

subsection.sentence: Figure 4.15.9: \operatorname{arcsin}\left(x+iy\right) (principal value). There are branch cuts along the real axis from -\infty to -1 and 1 to \infty .
Figure 4.15.11: \operatorname{arctan}\left(x+iy\right) (principal value). There are branch cuts along the imaginary axis from -i\infty to -i and i to i\infty .
Figure 4.15.13: \operatorname{arccsc}\left(x+iy\right) (principal value). There is a branch cut along the real axis from -1 to 1 .

para.sentence: The corresponding surfaces for \cos\left(x+iy\right) , \cot\left(x+iy\right) , and \sec\left(x+iy\right) are similar.

In consequence of the identities \cos\left(x+iy\right)=\sin\left(x+\tfrac{1}{2}\pi+iy\right), , \cot\left(x+iy\right)=-\tan\left(x+\tfrac{1}{2}\pi+iy\right), , \sec\left(x+iy\right)=\csc\left(x+\tfrac{1}{2}\pi+iy\right), they can be obtained by translating the surfaces shown in FiguresLABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.5, LABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.8,LABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.9 by -\tfrac{1}{2}\pi parallel to the x -axis, and adjusting the phase coloring in the case of Figure LABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.8.

The corresponding surfaces for \operatorname{arccos}\left(x+iy\right) , \operatorname{arccot}\left(x+iy\right) , \operatorname{arcsec}\left(x+iy\right) can be visualized from Figures LABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.14,LABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.20,LABEL:fig:EF.HYP.GRV.21 with the aid of equations (LABEL:eq:EF.CJ.AS.1)–(LABEL:eq:EF.CJ.AS.3).

section.title: Special Values and Limits
section.sentence: Table 4.17.1: Trigonometric functions: values at multiples of \frac{1}{12}\pi .

para.sentence: \lim_{z\to 0}\frac{\sin z}{z}=1, , \lim_{z\to 0}\frac{\tan z}{z}=1.
, \lim_{z\to 0}\frac{1-\cos z}{z^{2}}=\frac{1}{2}.
\frac{2x}{\pi}\leq\sin x\leq x, subject to 0\leq x\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi.
x\leq\tan x, subject to 0\leq x<\frac{1}{2}\pi, \cos x\leq\frac{\sin x}{x}\leq 1, subject to 0\leq x\leq\pi, \pi<\frac{\sin\left(\pi x\right)}{x(1-x)}\leq 4, subject to 0<x<1.

With z=x+iy , |\sinh y|\leq|\sin z|\leq\cosh y, |\sinh y|\leq|\cos z|\leq\cosh y, |\csc z|\leq\operatorname{csch}|y|, |\cos z|\leq\cosh|z|, |\sin z|\leq\sinh|z|, |\cos z|<2, |\sin z|\leq\tfrac{6}{5}|z| subject to |z|<1.
For more inequalities see ( , pp. 101–111) , ( , pp. 235–265) , and ( , pp. 250–254) .
In (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.CV)–(LABEL:eq:EF.CI.DB), B_{n} are the Bernoulli numbers and E_{n} are the Euler numbers (§§LABEL:sec:BP.DE.BNP–LABEL:sec:BP.DE.ENP).

\tan z=z+\frac{z^{3}}{3}+\frac{2}{15}z^{5}+\frac{17}{315}z^{7}+\cdots+\frac{(- 1)^{n-1}2^{2n}(2^{2n}-1)B_{2n}}{(2n)!}z^{2n-1}+\cdots, subject to |z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi, \csc z=\frac{1}{z}+\frac{z}{6}+\frac{7}{360}z^{3}+\frac{31}{15120}z^{5}+\cdots +\frac{(-1)^{n-1}2(2^{2n-1}-1)B_{2n}}{(2n)!}z^{2n-1}+\cdots, subject to 0<|z|<\pi, \sec z=1+\frac{z^{2}}{2}+\frac{5}{24}z^{4}+\frac{61}{720}z^{6}+\cdots+\frac{(- 1)^{n}E_{2n}}{(2n)!}z^{2n}+\cdots, subject to |z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi, \cot z=\frac{1}{z}-\frac{z}{3}-\frac{z^{3}}{45}-\frac{2}{945}z^{5}-\cdots- \frac{(-1)^{n-1}2^{2n}B_{2n}}{(2n)!}z^{2n-1}-\cdots, subject to 0<|z|<\pi, \ln\left(\frac{\sin z}{z}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}2^{2n-1}B_{2 n}}{n(2n)!}z^{2n}, subject to |z|<\pi, \ln\left(\cos z\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}2^{2n-1}(2^{2n}-1)B_{2 n}}{n(2n)!}z^{2n}, subject to |z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi, \ln\left(\frac{\tan z}{z}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n-1}2^{2n}(2^{ 2n-1}-1)B_{2n}}{n(2n)!}z^{2n}, subject to |z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi.

\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\sin z=\cos z, , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\cos z=-\sin z, , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\tan z={\sec^{2}}z, , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\csc z=-\csc z\cot z, , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\sec z=\sec z\tan z, , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\cot z=-{\csc^{2}}z, , \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}\sin z=\sin\left(z+\tfrac{1}{2}n\pi \right), , \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{n}}\cos z=\cos\left(z+\tfrac{1}{2}n\pi \right).

With a\neq 0 , the general solutions of the differential equations \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+a^{2}w=0, , \left(\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}\right)^{2}+a^{2}w^{2}=1, , \frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}-a^{2}w^{2}=1, are respectively w=A\cos\left(az\right)+B\sin\left(az\right), , w=(1/a)\sin\left(az+c\right), , w=(1/a)\tan\left(az+c\right), where A,B,c are arbitrary constants.
For other differential equations see ( , pp. 355–358 and 396–400) .
\sin u\pm\cos u=\sqrt{2}\sin\left(u\pm\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right)=\pm\sqrt{2}\cos \left(u\mp\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right).

\sin\left(u\pm v\right)=\sin u\cos v\pm\cos u\sin v, , \cos\left(u\pm v\right)=\cos u\cos v\mp\sin u\sin v, , \tan\left(u\pm v\right)=\frac{\tan u\pm\tan v}{1\mp\tan u\tan v}, , \cot\left(u\pm v\right)=\frac{\pm\cot u\cot v-1}{\cot u\pm\cot v}.

\sin u+\sin v=2\sin\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\cos\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right), , \sin u-\sin v=2\cos\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\sin\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right), , \cos u+\cos v=2\cos\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\cos\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right), , \cos u-\cos v=-2\sin\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\sin\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right).
\tan u\pm\tan v=\frac{\sin\left(u\pm v\right)}{\cos u\cos v}, , \cot u\pm\cot v=\frac{\sin\left(v\pm u\right)}{\sin u\sin v}.
2\sin u\sin v=\cos\left(u-v\right)-\cos\left(u+v\right), 2\cos u\cos v=\cos\left(u-v\right)+\cos\left(u+v\right), 2\sin u\cos v=\sin\left(u-v\right)+\sin\left(u+v\right).

{\sin^{2}}u-{\sin^{2}}v=\sin\left(u+v\right)\sin\left(u-v\right), , {\cos^{2}}u-{\cos^{2}}v=-\sin\left(u+v\right)\sin\left(u-v\right), , {\cos^{2}}u-{\sin^{2}}v=\cos\left(u+v\right)\cos\left(u-v\right).

\sin\frac{z}{2}=\pm\left(\frac{1-\cos z}{2}\right)^{1/2}, \cos\frac{z}{2}=\pm\left(\frac{1+\cos z}{2}\right)^{1/2}, \tan\frac{z}{2}=\pm\left(\frac{1-\cos z}{1+\cos z}\right)^{1/2}=\frac{1-\cos z }{\sin z}=\frac{\sin z}{1+\cos z}.
In (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.MA.1)–(LABEL:eq:EF.CI.MA.3)Table LABEL:tab:EF.CI.SI and analytic continuation will assist in resolving sign ambiguities.
\sin\left(-z\right)=-\sin z, , \cos\left(-z\right)=\cos z, , \tan\left(-z\right)=-\tan z.

\sin\left(2z\right)=2\sin z\cos z=\frac{2\tan z}{1+{\tan^{2}}z}, \cos\left(2z\right)=2{\cos^{2}}z-1=1-2{\sin^{2}}z={\cos^{2}}z-{\sin^{2}}z= \frac{1-{\tan^{2}}z}{1+{\tan^{2}}z}, \tan\left(2z\right)=\frac{2\tan z}{1-{\tan^{2}}z}=\frac{2\cot z}{{\cot^{2}}z-1 }=\frac{2}{\cot z-\tan z}.
\sin\left(3z\right)=3\sin z-4{\sin^{3}}z, , \cos\left(3z\right)=-3\cos z+4{\cos^{3}}z, , \sin\left(4z\right)=8{\cos^{3}}z\sin z-4\cos z\sin z, , \cos\left(4z\right)=8{\cos^{4}}z-8{\cos^{2}}z+1.
When n\in\mathbb{Z} \cos\left(nz\right)+i\sin\left(nz\right)=(\cos z+i\sin z)^{n}.
This result is also valid when n is fractional or complex, provided that -\pi\leq\Re z\leq\pi.
\sin\left(nz\right)=2^{n-1}\prod_{k=0}^{n-1}\sin\left(z+\frac{k\pi}{n}\right), subject to n=1,2,3,\dots.
If t=\tan\left(\frac{1}{2}z\right) , then \sin z=\frac{2t}{1+t^{2}}, \cos z=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, \mathrm{d}z=\frac{2}{1+t^{2}}\mathrm{d}t.

With z=x+iy \sin z=\sin x\cosh y+\mathrm{i}\cos x\sinh y, \cos z=\cos x\cosh y-\mathrm{i}\sin x\sinh y, \tan z=\frac{\sin\left(2x\right)+\mathrm{i}\sinh\left(2y\right)}{\cos\left(2x \right)+\cosh\left(2y\right)}, \cot z=\frac{\sin\left(2x\right)-\mathrm{i}\sinh\left(2y\right)}{\cosh\left(2y \right)-\cos\left(2x\right)}.

|\sin z|=({\sin^{2}}x+{\sinh^{2}}y)^{1/2}=\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\left(\cosh\left(2 y\right)-\cos\left(2x\right)\right)\right)^{1/2}, |\cos z|=({\cos^{2}}x+{\sinh^{2}}y)^{1/2}=\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(\cosh\left(2y \right)+\cos\left(2x\right))\right)^{1/2}, |\tan z|=\left(\frac{\cosh\left(2y\right)-\cos\left(2x\right)}{\cosh\left(2y \right)+\cos\left(2x\right)}\right)^{1/2}.
\sin z=z\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(1-\frac{z^{2}}{n^{2}\pi^{2}}\right), , \cos z=\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(1-\frac{4z^{2}}{(2n-1)^{2}\pi^{2}}\right).

When z\neq n\pi , n\in\mathbb{Z} , \cot z=\frac{1}{z}+2z\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{z^{2}-n^{2}\pi^{2}}, , {\csc^{2}}z=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(z-n\pi)^{2}}, , \csc z=\frac{1}{z}+2z\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}}{z^{2}-n^{2}\pi^{2}}.

The general values of the inverse trigonometric functions are defined by \operatorname{Arcsin}z=\int_{0}^{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{(1-t^{2})^{1/2}}, , \operatorname{Arccos}z=\int_{z}^{1}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{(1-t^{2})^{1/2}}, , \operatorname{Arctan}z=\int_{0}^{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{1+t^{2}}, subject to z\neq\pm\mathrm{i}, , \operatorname{Arccsc}z=\operatorname{Arcsin}\left(1/z\right), , \operatorname{Arcsec}z=\operatorname{Arccos}\left(1/z\right), , \operatorname{Arccot}z=\operatorname{Arctan}\left(1/z\right).
In (LABEL:eq:EF.INV.GD.1) and (LABEL:eq:EF.INV.GD.2) the integration paths maynot pass through either of the points t=\pm 1.
The function (1-t^{2})^{1/2} assumes its principal value when t\in(-1,1) ; elsewhere on the integration paths the branch is determined by continuity.
In (LABEL:eq:EF.INV.GD.3) the integration path may not intersect \pm i.
Each of the six functions is a multivalued function of z.
\operatorname{Arctan}z and \operatorname{Arccot}z have branch points at z=\pm\mathrm{i} ; the other four functions have branch points at z=\pm 1.

subsection.title: Principal Values

para.sentence: The principal values (or principal branches) of the inverse sine, cosine, and tangent are obtained by introducing cuts in the z -plane as indicated in Figures LABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(i) and LABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(ii), and requiring the integration paths in (LABEL:eq:EF.INV.GD.1)–(LABEL:eq:EF.INV.GD.3) not to cross these cuts.
Compare the principal value of the logarithm (§LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG).
The principal branches are denoted by \operatorname{arcsin}z , \operatorname{arccos}z , \operatorname{arctan}z , respectively.
Each is two-valued on the corresponding cuts,and each is real on the part of the real axis that remains after deleting the intersections with the corresponding cuts.

The principal values of the inverse cosecant, secant, and cotangent are given by \operatorname{arccsc}z=\operatorname{arcsin}\left(1/z\right), , \operatorname{arcsec}z=\operatorname{arccos}\left(1/z\right).
, \operatorname{arccot}z=\operatorname{arctan}\left(1/z\right), subject to z\neq\pm\mathrm{i}.
These functions are analytic in the cut plane depicted in FiguresLABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(iii) and LABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(iv).
Except where indicated otherwise, it is assumed throughout the DLMF that the inverse trigonometric functions assume their principal values.

subsection.sentence: Figure 4.23.1: z -plane. Branch cuts for the inverse trigonometric functions.

para.sentence: Graphs of the principal values for real arguments are given in §LABEL:sec:EF.HYP.GRV.
This section also includes conformal mappings, and surface plots for complex arguments.
\operatorname{arcsin}\left(-z\right)=-\operatorname{arcsin}z, , \operatorname{arccos}\left(-z\right)=\pi-\operatorname{arccos}z.
, \operatorname{arctan}\left(-z\right)=-\operatorname{arctan}z, subject to z\neq\pm\mathrm{i}.
, \operatorname{arccsc}\left(-z\right)=-\operatorname{arccsc}z, , \operatorname{arcsec}\left(-z\right)=\pi-\operatorname{arcsec}z.
, \operatorname{arccot}\left(-z\right)=-\operatorname{arccot}z, subject to z\neq\pm\mathrm{i}.
, \operatorname{arccos}z=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi-\operatorname{arcsin}z, , \operatorname{arcsec}z=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi-\operatorname{arccsc}z.
, \operatorname{arccot}z=\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\pi-\operatorname{arctan}z, subject to \Re z\gtrless 0.
Throughout this subsection all quantities assume their principal values.
\operatorname{arcsin}z=-i\ln\left((1-z^{2})^{1/2}+iz\right), subject to z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty); compare Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(i).

On the cuts \operatorname{arcsin}x=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi\pm i\ln\left((x^{2}-1)^{1/2}+x\right), subject to x\in[1,\infty), , \operatorname{arcsin}x=-\tfrac{1}{2}\pi\pm i\ln\left((x^{2}-1)^{1/2}-x\right), subject to x\in(-\infty,-1], upper signs being taken on upper sides, and lower signs on lower sides.
\operatorname{arccos}z=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi+i\ln\left((1-z^{2})^{1/2}+iz\right), subject to z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty); compare Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(i).

An equivalent definition is \operatorname{arccos}z=-2i\ln\left(\left(\frac{1+z}{2}\right)^{1/2}+i\left( \frac{1-z}{2}\right)^{1/2}\right), subject to z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty); see ( ) .

On the cuts \operatorname{arccos}x=\mp i\ln\left((x^{2}-1)^{1/2}+x\right), subject to x\in[1,\infty), , \operatorname{arccos}x=\pi\mp i\ln\left((x^{2}-1)^{1/2}-x\right), subject to x\in(-\infty,-1], the upper/lower signs corresponding to the upper/lower sides.
\operatorname{arctan}z=\frac{i}{2}\ln\left(\frac{i+z}{i-z}\right), subject to z/i\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,-1]\cup[1,\infty); compare Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(ii).

On the cuts \operatorname{arctan}\left(iy\right)=\pm\frac{1}{2}\pi+\frac{i}{2}\ln\left( \frac{y+1}{y-1}\right), subject to y\in(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty), the upper/lower sign corresponding to the right/left side.
For the corresponding results for \operatorname{arccsc}z , \operatorname{arcsec}z , and \operatorname{arccot}z , use (LABEL:eq:EF.INV.PV.1)–(LABEL:eq:EF.INV.PV.3).
Care needs to be taken on the cuts, for example, if 0<x<\infty then 1/(x+i0)=(1/x)-i0.

With k\in\mathbb{Z} , the general solutions of the equations z=\sin w, , z=\cos w, , z=\tan w, are respectively w=\operatorname{Arcsin}z=(-1)^{k}\operatorname{arcsin}z+k\pi, , w=\operatorname{Arccos}z=\pm\operatorname{arccos}z+2k\pi, , w=\operatorname{Arctan}z=\operatorname{arctan}z+k\pi, subject to z\neq\pm\mathrm{i}.

\operatorname{arcsin}z=\operatorname{arcsin}\beta+\mathrm{i}\operatorname{sign }\left(y\right)\ln\left(\alpha+(\alpha^{2}-1)^{1/2}\right), , \operatorname{arccos}z=\operatorname{arccos}\beta-\mathrm{i}\operatorname{sign }\left(y\right)\ln\left(\alpha+(\alpha^{2}-1)^{1/2}\right), , \operatorname{arctan}z=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{arctan}\left(\frac{2x}{1-x^{2 }-y^{2}}\right)+\tfrac{1}{4}i\ln\left(\frac{x^{2}+(y+1)^{2}}{x^{2}+(y-1)^{2}} \right), where z=x+\mathrm{i}y and \pm z\notin(1,\infty) in (LABEL:eq:EF.CJ.RIP.1) and (LABEL:eq:EF.CJ.RIP.2), and \left|z\right|<1 in (LABEL:eq:EF.CJ.RIP.3).

subsection.title: Special Values and Interrelations
subsection.sentence: Table 4.23.1: Inverse trigonometric functions: principal values at 0, \pm 1 , \pm\infty .

para.sentence: For interrelations see Table LABEL:tab:EF.CI.TR.
For example, from the headingand last entry in the penultimate column we have \operatorname{arcsec}a=\operatorname{arccot}\left((a^{2}-1)^{-1/2}\right).
The Gudermannian \operatorname{gd}\left(x\right) is defined by \operatorname{gd}\left(x\right)=\int_{0}^{x}\operatorname{sech}t\mathrm{d}t, subject to -\infty<x<\infty.

Equivalently, \operatorname{gd}\left(x\right)=2\operatorname{arctan}\left(e^{x}\right)- \tfrac{1}{2}\pi\\ =\operatorname{arcsin}\left(\tanh x\right)=\operatorname{arccsc}\left(\coth x \right)\\ =\operatorname{arccos}\left(\operatorname{sech}x\right)=\operatorname{arcsec} \left(\cosh x\right)\\ =\operatorname{arctan}\left(\sinh x\right)=\operatorname{arccot}\left( \operatorname{csch}x\right).
The inverse Gudermannian function is given by {\operatorname{gd}^{-1}}\left(x\right)=\int_{0}^{x}\sec t\mathrm{d}t, subject to -\frac{1}{2}\pi<x<\frac{1}{2}\pi.

Equivalently, and again when -\frac{1}{2}\pi<x<\frac{1}{2}\pi , {\operatorname{gd}^{-1}}\left(x\right)=\ln\tan\left(\tfrac{1}{2}x+\tfrac{1}{4} \pi\right)=\ln\left(\sec x+\tan x\right)=\operatorname{arcsinh}\left(\tan x \right)=\operatorname{arccsch}\left(\cot x\right)=\operatorname{arccosh}\left( \sec x\right)=\operatorname{arcsech}\left(\cos x\right)=\operatorname{arctanh} \left(\sin x\right)=\operatorname{arccoth}\left(\csc x\right).
\operatorname{arcsin}z=z+\frac{1}{2}\frac{z^{3}}{3}+\frac{1\cdot 3}{2\cdot 4} \frac{z^{5}}{5}+\frac{1\cdot 3\cdot 5}{2\cdot 4\cdot 6}\frac{z^{7}}{7}+\cdots, subject to |z|\leq 1.
\operatorname{arctan}z=z-\frac{z^{3}}{3}+\frac{z^{5}}{5}-\frac{z^{7}}{7}+\cdots, subject to \left|z\right|\leq 1, z\neq\pm\mathrm{i}.
\operatorname{arctan}z=\pm\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{1}{z}+\frac{1}{3z^{3}}-\frac{1}{ 5z^{5}}+\cdots, subject to \Re z\gtrless 0, |z|\geq 1.

\operatorname{arctan}z=\frac{z}{z^{2}+1}\*\left(1+\frac{2}{3}\frac{z^{2}}{1+z^ {2}}+\frac{2\cdot 4}{3\cdot 5}\left(\frac{z^{2}}{1+z^{2}}\right)^{2}+\cdots \right), subject to \Re(z^{2})>-\tfrac{1}{2}, which requires z (=x+iy) to lie between the two rectangular hyperbolas given by x^{2}-y^{2}=-\tfrac{1}{2}.

\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\operatorname{arcsin}z=(1-z^{2})^{-1/2}, , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\operatorname{arccos}z=-(1-z^{2})^{-1/2}, , \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\operatorname{arctan}z=\frac{1}{1+z^{2}}.
, \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\operatorname{arccsc}z=\mp\frac{1}{z(z^{2}-1)^{1 /2}}, subject to \Re z\gtrless 0.
, \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\operatorname{arcsec}z=\pm\frac{1}{z(z^{2}-1)^{1 /2}}, subject to \Re z\gtrless 0.
, \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\operatorname{arccot}z=-\frac{1}{1+z^{2}}.

\operatorname{Arcsin}u\pm\operatorname{Arcsin}v=\operatorname{Arcsin}\left(u(1 -v^{2})^{1/2}\pm v(1-u^{2})^{1/2}\right), \operatorname{Arccos}u\pm\operatorname{Arccos}v=\operatorname{Arccos}\left(uv \mp((1-u^{2})(1-v^{2}))^{1/2}\right), \operatorname{Arctan}u\pm\operatorname{Arctan}v=\operatorname{Arctan}\left( \frac{u\pm v}{1\mp uv}\right), \operatorname{Arcsin}u\pm\operatorname{Arccos}v=\operatorname{Arcsin}\left(uv \pm((1-u^{2})(1-v^{2}))^{1/2}\right)=\operatorname{Arccos}\left(v(1-u^{2})^{1/ 2}\mp u(1-v^{2})^{1/2}\right), \operatorname{Arctan}u\pm\operatorname{Arccot}v=\operatorname{Arctan}\left( \frac{uv\pm 1}{v\mp u}\right)=\operatorname{Arccot}\left(\frac{v\mp u}{uv\pm 1 }\right).
The above equations are interpreted in the sense that every value of the left-hand side is a value of the right-hand side and vice versa.
All square roots have either possible value.
\tan z=\cfrac{z}{1-\cfrac{z^{2}}{3-\cfrac{z^{2}}{5-\cfrac{z^{2}}{7-}}}}\cdots, subject to z\neq\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, \pm\tfrac{3}{2}\pi, \dots.

\tan\left(az\right)=\cfrac{a\tan z}{1+\cfrac{(1-a^{2}){\tan^{2}}z}{3+\cfrac{(4 -a^{2}){\tan^{2}}z}{5+\cfrac{(9-a^{2}){\tan^{2}}z}{7+}}}}\cdots, subject to |\Re z|<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi, az\neq\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\pi,\pm\tfrac{3}{2}\pi,\dots.

\frac{\operatorname{arcsin}z}{\sqrt{1-z^{2}}}=\cfrac{z}{1-\cfrac{1\cdot 2z^{2} }{3-\cfrac{1\cdot 2z^{2}}{5-\cfrac{3\cdot 4z^{2}}{7-\cfrac{3\cdot 4z^{2}}{9-}} }}}\cdots, valid when z lies in the open cut plane shown in Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.TRIG(i).

\int\operatorname{arcsin}x\mathrm{d}x=x\operatorname{arcsin}x+(1-x^{2})^{1/2}, subject to -1<x<1, \int\operatorname{arccos}x\mathrm{d}x=x\operatorname{arccos}x-(1-x^{2})^{1/2}, subject to -1<x<1.

\int\operatorname{arctan}x\mathrm{d}x=x\operatorname{arctan}x-\tfrac{1}{2}\ln \left(1+x^{2}\right), subject to -\infty<x<\infty, \int\operatorname{arccsc}x\mathrm{d}x=x\operatorname{arccsc}x+\ln\left(x+(x^{2 }-1)^{1/2}\right), subject to 1<x<\infty, \int\operatorname{arcsec}x\mathrm{d}x=x\operatorname{arcsec}x-\ln\left(x+(x^{2 }-1)^{1/2}\right), subject to 1<x<\infty, \int\operatorname{arccot}x\mathrm{d}x=x\operatorname{arccot}x+\tfrac{1}{2}\ln \left(1+x^{2}\right), subject to 0<x<\infty.

\sinh z=\frac{e^{z}-e^{-z}}{2}, , \cosh z=\frac{e^{z}+e^{-z}}{2}, , \cosh z\pm\sinh z=e^{\pm z}, , \tanh z=\frac{\sinh z}{\cosh z}, , \operatorname{csch}z=\frac{1}{\sinh z}, , \operatorname{sech}z=\frac{1}{\cosh z}, , \coth z=\frac{1}{\tanh z}.

\sin\left(iz\right)=i\sinh z, , \cos\left(iz\right)=\cosh z, , \tan\left(iz\right)=i\tanh z, , \csc\left(iz\right)=-i\operatorname{csch}z, , \sec\left(iz\right)=\operatorname{sech}z, , \cot\left(iz\right)=-i\coth z.
As a consequence, many properties of the hyperbolic functions follow immediately from the corresponding properties of the trigonometric functions.
The functions \sinh z and \cosh z have period 2\pi i , and \tanh z has period \pi i.
The zeros of \sinh z and \cosh z are z=ik\pi and z=i\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)\pi , respectively, k\in\mathbb{Z}.

With a\neq 0 , the general solutions of the differential equations \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}-a^{2}w=0, , \left(\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}\right)^{2}-a^{2}w^{2}=1, , \left(\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}\right)^{2}-a^{2}w^{2}=-1, , \frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}+a^{2}w^{2}=1, are respectively w=A\cosh\left(az\right)+B\sinh\left(az\right), , w=(1/a)\sinh\left(az+c\right), , w=(1/a)\cosh\left(az+c\right), , w=(1/a)\coth\left(az+c\right), where A,B,c are arbitrary constants.
For other differential equations see ( , pp. 289–400) .

\sinh\left(u\pm v\right)=\sinh u\cosh v\pm\cosh u\sinh v, , \cosh\left(u\pm v\right)=\cosh u\cosh v\pm\sinh u\sinh v, , \tanh\left(u\pm v\right)=\frac{\tanh u\pm\tanh v}{1\pm\tanh u\tanh v}, , \coth\left(u\pm v\right)=\frac{\pm\coth u\coth v+1}{\coth u\pm\coth v}.

\sinh u+\sinh v=2\sinh\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\cosh\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right), , \sinh u-\sinh v=2\cosh\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\sinh\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right), , \cosh u+\cosh v=2\cosh\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\cosh\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right), , \cosh u-\cosh v=2\sinh\left(\frac{u+v}{2}\right)\sinh\left(\frac{u-v}{2}\right), , \tanh u\pm\tanh v=\frac{\sinh\left(u\pm v\right)}{\cosh u\cosh v}, , \coth u\pm\coth v=\frac{\sinh\left(v\pm u\right)}{\sinh u\sinh v}.
{\cosh^{2}}z-{\sinh^{2}}z=1, {\operatorname{sech}^{2}}z=1-{\tanh^{2}}z, {\operatorname{csch}^{2}}z={\coth^{2}}z-1.
2\sinh u\sinh v=\cosh\left(u+v\right)-\cosh\left(u-v\right), , 2\cosh u\cosh v=\cosh\left(u+v\right)+\cosh\left(u-v\right), , 2\sinh u\cosh v=\sinh\left(u+v\right)+\sinh\left(u-v\right).

{\sinh^{2}}u-{\sinh^{2}}v=\sinh\left(u+v\right)\sinh\left(u-v\right), , {\cosh^{2}}u-{\cosh^{2}}v=\sinh\left(u+v\right)\sinh\left(u-v\right), , {\sinh^{2}}u+{\cosh^{2}}v=\cosh\left(u+v\right)\cosh\left(u-v\right).

The square roots assume their principal value on the positive real axis, and are determined by continuity elsewhere.
\sinh\left(-z\right)=-\sinh z, , \cosh\left(-z\right)=\cosh z, , \tanh\left(-z\right)=-\tanh z.

\sinh\left(2z\right)=2\sinh z\cosh z=\frac{2\tanh z}{1-{\tanh^{2}}z}, \cosh\left(2z\right)=2{\cosh^{2}}z-1=2{\sinh^{2}}z+1\\ ={\cosh^{2}}z+{\sinh^{2}}z, \tanh\left(2z\right)=\frac{2\tanh z}{1+{\tanh^{2}}z}, \sinh\left(3z\right)=3\sinh z+4{\sinh^{3}}z, \cosh\left(3z\right)=-3\cosh z+4{\cosh^{3}}z, \sinh\left(4z\right)=4{\sinh^{3}}z\cosh z+4{\cosh^{3}}z\sinh z, , \cosh\left(4z\right)={\cosh^{4}}z+6{\sinh^{2}}z{\cosh^{2}}z+{\sinh^{4}}z.
\cosh\left(nz\right)\pm\sinh\left(nz\right)=(\cosh z\pm\sinh z)^{n}, subject to n\in\mathbb{Z}.

With z=x+iy \sinh z=\sinh x\cos y+i\cosh x\sin y, , \cosh z=\cosh x\cos y+i\sinh x\sin y, , \tanh z=\frac{\sinh\left(2x\right)+i\sin\left(2y\right)}{\cosh\left(2x\right)+ \cos\left(2y\right)}, , \coth z=\frac{\sinh\left(2x\right)-i\sin\left(2y\right)}{\cosh\left(2x\right)- \cos\left(2y\right)}.

|\sinh z|=({\sinh^{2}}x+{\sin^{2}}y)^{1/2}=\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(\cosh\left(2x \right)-\cos\left(2y\right))\right)^{1/2}, |\cosh z|=({\sinh^{2}}x+{\cos^{2}}y)^{1/2}=\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(\cosh\left(2x \right)+\cos\left(2y\right))\right)^{1/2}, |\tanh z|=\left(\frac{\cosh\left(2x\right)-\cos\left(2y\right)}{\cosh\left(2x \right)+\cos\left(2y\right)}\right)^{1/2}.
\sinh z=z\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(1+\frac{z^{2}}{n^{2}\pi^{2}}\right), , \cosh z=\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(1+\frac{4z^{2}}{(2n-1)^{2}\pi^{2}}\right).

When z\neq n\pi i , n\in\mathbb{Z} , \coth z=\frac{1}{z}+2z\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{z^{2}+n^{2}\pi^{2}}, , {\operatorname{csch}^{2}}z=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(z-n\pi i)^{2}}, , \operatorname{csch}z=\frac{1}{z}+2z\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}}{z^{2}+n^ {2}\pi^{2}}.

The general values of the inverse hyperbolic functions are defined by \operatorname{Arcsinh}z=\int_{0}^{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{(1+t^{2})^{1/2}}, , \operatorname{Arccosh}z=\int_{1}^{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{(t^{2}-1)^{1/2}}, , \operatorname{Arctanh}z=\int_{0}^{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{1-t^{2}}, subject to z\neq\pm 1, , \operatorname{Arccsch}z=\operatorname{Arcsinh}\left(1/z\right), , \operatorname{Arcsech}z=\operatorname{Arccosh}\left(1/z\right), , \operatorname{Arccoth}z=\operatorname{Arctanh}\left(1/z\right).
In (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.GD.1) the integration path may not pass through either of the points t=\pm i , and the function (1+t^{2})^{1/2} assumes its principal value when t is real.
In (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.GD.2) the integration path may not pass through either of the points \pm 1 , and the function (t^{2}-1)^{1/2} assumes its principal value when t\in(1,\infty).
Elsewhere on the integration paths in (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.GD.1) and (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.GD.2) the branches are determined by continuity.
In (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.GD.3) the integration path may not intersect \pm 1.
Each of the six functions is a multivalued function of z.
\operatorname{Arcsinh}z and \operatorname{Arccsch}z have branch points at z=\pm i ; the other four functions have branch points at z=\pm 1.

subsection.title: Principal Values

para.sentence: The principal values (or principal branches) of the inverse \sinh , \cosh , and \tanh are obtained by introducing cuts in the z -plane as indicated in Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.HYPERB(i)-(iii), and requiring the integration paths in (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.GD.1)–(LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.GD.3) not to cross these cuts.
Compare the principal value of the logarithm (§LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG).
The principal branches are denoted by \operatorname{arcsinh} , \operatorname{arccosh} , \operatorname{arctanh} respectively.
Each is two-valued on the corresponding cut(s), and each is real on the part of the real axis that remains after deleting the intersections with the corresponding cuts.

The principal values of the inverse hyperbolic cosecant, hyperbolic secant, and hyperbolic tangent are given by \operatorname{arccsch}z=\operatorname{arcsinh}\left(1/z\right), , \operatorname{arcsech}z=\operatorname{arccosh}\left(1/z\right).
, \operatorname{arccoth}z=\operatorname{arctanh}\left(1/z\right), subject to z\neq\pm 1.
These functions are analytic in the cut plane depicted in FigureLABEL:fig:EF.IH.HYPERB(iv), (v), (vi), respectively.
Except where indicated otherwise, it is assumed throughout the DLMF that the inverse hyperbolic functions assume their principal values.

On the cuts \operatorname{arcsinh}\left(iy\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi i\pm\ln\left((y^{2}-1)^{ 1/2}+y\right), subject to y\in[1,\infty), \operatorname{arcsinh}\left(iy\right)=-\tfrac{1}{2}\pi i\pm\ln\left((y^{2}-1)^ {1/2}-y\right), subject to y\in(-\infty,-1], the upper/lower signs corresponding to the right/left sides.

\operatorname{arccosh}z=\ln\left(\pm(z^{2}-1)^{1/2}+z\right), subject to z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,1), the upper or lower sign being taken according as \Re z\gtrless 0 ; compare Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.HYPERB(ii).
Also, \operatorname{arccosh}\left(\mathrm{i}y\right)=\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\pi\mathrm{i}+ \ln\left((y^{2}+1)^{1/2}\pm y\right), subject to y\gtrless 0.
It should be noted that the imaginary axis is not a cut; the function defined by (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.LF.4) and (LABEL:eq:EF.IHF.LF.4a) is analytic everywhere except on (-\infty,1].
Compare Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.HYPERB(ii).
An equivalent definition is \operatorname{arccosh}z=2\ln\left(\left(\frac{z+1}{2}\right)^{1/2}+\left(\frac {z-1}{2}\right)^{1/2}\right), subject to z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,1); see ( ) .
On the part of the cuts from -1 to 1 \operatorname{arccosh}x=\pm\ln\left(i(1-x^{2})^{1/2}+x\right), subject to x\in(-1,1], the upper/lower sign corresponding to the upper/lower side.
On the part of the cut from -\infty to -1 \operatorname{arccosh}x=\pm\pi i+\ln\left((x^{2}-1)^{1/2}-x\right), subject to x\in(-\infty,-1], the upper/lower sign corresponding to the upper/lower side.
\operatorname{arctanh}z=\tfrac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1+z}{1-z}\right), subject to z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,-1]\cup[1,\infty); compare Figure LABEL:fig:EF.IH.HYPERB(iii).

Let p(\neq 0) and q be real constants and A=\left(-\tfrac{4}{3}p\right)^{1/2}, B=\left(\tfrac{4}{3}p\right)^{1/2}.
The roots of z^{3}+pz+q=0 are: A\sin a , A\sin\left(a+\frac{2}{3}\pi\right) , and A\sin\left(a+\frac{4}{3}\pi\right) , with \sin\left(3a\right)=4q/A^{3} , when 4p^{3}+27q^{2}\leq 0.
A\cosh a , A\cosh\left(a+\frac{2}{3}\pi i\right) , and A\cosh\left(a+\frac{4}{3}\pi i\right) , with \cosh\left(3a\right)=-4q/A^{3} , when p<0 , q<0 , and 4p^{3}+27q^{2}>0.
B\sinh a , B\sinh\left(a+\frac{2}{3}\pi i\right) , and B\sinh\left(a+\frac{4}{3}\pi i\right) , with \sinh\left(3a\right)=-4q/B^{3} , when p>0.
Note that in Case (a) all the roots are real, whereas in Cases (b) and (c) there is one real root and a conjugate pair of complex roots.

The function \ln x can always be computed from its ascending power series after preliminary scaling.
Suppose first 1/10\leq x\leq 10.
Then we take square roots repeatedly until |y| is sufficiently small, where y=x^{2^{-m}}-1.
After computing \ln\left(1+y\right) from (LABEL:eq:EF.LO.LS) \ln x=2^{m}\ln\left(1+y\right).
For other values of x set x=10^{m}\xi , where 1/10\leq\xi\leq 10 and m\in\mathbb{Z}.
Then \ln x=\ln\xi+m\ln 10.
Let x have any real value.
First, rescale via m=\left\lfloor\frac{x}{\ln 10}+\frac{1}{2}\right\rfloor, y=x-m\ln 10.
Then e^{x}=10^{m}e^{y}, and since |y|\leq\frac{1}{2}\ln 10=1.15\dot s, e^{y} can be computed straightforwardly from (LABEL:eq:EF.EX.SA).
Let x have any real value.
We first compute \xi=x/\pi , followed by m=\left\lfloor\xi+\tfrac{1}{2}\right\rfloor, \theta=\pi(\xi-m).

Then \sin x=(-1)^{m}\sin\theta, \cos x=(-1)^{m}\cos\theta, and since |\theta|\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi=1.57\dot s, \sin\theta and \cos\theta can be computed straightforwardly from (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.CT) and (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.CU).
The other trigonometric functions can be found from the definitions (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.AC)–(LABEL:eq:EF.CI.AF).
The function \operatorname{arctan}x can always be computed from its ascending power series after preliminary transformations to reduce the size of x.
From (LABEL:eq:EF.ITF.AF.3) with u=v=((1+x^{2})^{1/2}-1)/x , we have 2\operatorname{arctan}\frac{x}{1+(1+x^{2})^{1/2}}=\operatorname{arctan}x, subject to 0<x<\infty.
Beginning with x_{0}=x , generate the sequence x_{n}=\frac{x_{n-1}}{1+(1+x^{2}_{n-1})^{1/2}}, subject to n=1,2,3,\dots, until x_{n} is sufficiently small.
We then compute \operatorname{arctan}x_{n} from (LABEL:eq:EF.ITF.PS.3), followed by \operatorname{arctan}x=2^{n}\operatorname{arctan}x_{n}.
Another method, when x is large, is to sum \operatorname{arctan}x=\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{3x^{3}}-\frac{1}{5x^ {5}}+\dots; compare (LABEL:eq:EF.ITF.PS.4).
From (LABEL:eq:EF.ITF.PS.3)
\operatorname{arctan}x_{4}=0.09160\dot s. From (LABEL:eq:EF.MOC.RV.10)
\operatorname{arctan}x=16\operatorname{arctan}x_{4}=1.46563\dots.
As a check, from (LABEL:eq:EF.MOC.RV.11)
\operatorname{arctan}x=1.57079\ldots-0.10555\ldots+0.00039\ldots-\cdots=1.4656 3\dots.
For the remaining inverse trigonometric functions, we may use the identities provided by the fourth row of Table LABEL:tab:EF.CI.TR.
For example, \operatorname{arcsin}x=\operatorname{arctan}\left(x(1-x^{2})^{-1/2}\right).

All scientific programming languages, libraries, and systems support computation of at least some of the elementary functions in standard floating-point arithmetic (§LABEL:sec:NM.AEM.ARITH).
These will not be listed here.
